text: Whether Trump is fiddling these days or not, one thing is certain: in a Nero-like fashion, he continues to be irresponsibly unresponsive to the crisis caused by Covid-19.
label: Argument_against
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: One reason may be that, however inadvertently, the arrival of the pandemic has helped green-light plans and projects he’s held dear to his heart and that had, before the crisis, repeatedly encountered opposition.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Here are six examples of how the coronavirus, like a malign magic wand, has helped cast a disempowering spell over that opposition and so furthered Trump’s long-term goals.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: 1) The Southern Border: Since the day he entered the Oval Office, Trump has been focused on closing and sealing the border between Mexico and the United States.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Incrementally, his administration had moved from incarcerating upwards of 50,000 migrants and asylum seekers attempting to enter the United States at that border to — in the wake of the covid-19 — closing it completely to nonessential traffic and anyone trying to claim asylum.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Migrants who enter the U.S. illegally now will be returned to their native countries illegally.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: “Border security is health security,” the president claims .
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: In his persistent determination to close the border and punish migrants and asylum seekers alike, Trump has long allied with the Department of Justice to clear a path for his policies.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Attorney General William Barr’s department has, for instance, fought battle after battle to counter legal challenges to the prolonged detention of both migrants and asylum seekers, to prevent aid to sanctuary cities that offer protection to such migrants, to overrule Board of Immigration Appeals decisions, and to withhold bail from detained asylum seekers.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Until the covid-19 pandemic hit, however, the courts had increasingly been blocking some of these policies or putting them on hold.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Now, although judges, lawyers, and legal organizations have urged that immigration courts be closed until the pandemic lifts, they have generally remained open even, in some cases, after people in them had tested positive for the virus.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: The danger, not to say inhumanity, of all this, should be undeniable, but it does reflect President Trump’s ongoing immigration urges.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: In addition, the administration has doubled down on an existing policy of denying medical services to detained immigrants.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: This past winter, for instance, doctors were prevented from delivering flu vaccines to those in immigration detention camps.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Now, with more than 37,000 men, women, and children confined, the dangers of the virus spreading among them are obvious and inevitable.
label: Argument_against
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: As a former acting director of ICE puts it , the crowded conditions of detention, “which are designed to have people remain in close contact,” are “the opposite of the social distancing that is needed to save lives.”.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: 2) The Census: The census has long been a source of contention for this president.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: He waged a campaign to exclude non-citizens from participating in it only to be stalled in his efforts by the justices of the Supreme Court who decided that they needed more information to make a final decision on the subject.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: The issue at hand is that census results are used to determine how many congressional seats (based on population) are to be given to each state.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: If immigrants, both legal and undocumented, are not counted — and estimates are that roughly 6.5 million people fall into those two categories — then fewer politicians and less federal funding will be distributed to areas with more sizeable populations of them.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Originally, Trump responded to the Supreme Court’s decision by advocating that the census simply be put off.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Eventually, the administration backed down and the census was not delayed.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Now, however, the sands have shifted.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Covid-19 has turned the largely door-to-door gathering of census information into so many online , phone, and mail responses.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: The consequences of an inaccurate census could indeed prove dire.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: As National Public Radio’s Hansi Lo Wang reported , citing data collected by the Urban Institute, the 2020 census could result in “the worst undercount of black and Latino and Latina people in the U.S. since 1990.” According to one local San Francisco paper , “If the Census count is artificially low, the ramifications in this and every city will be real.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: It is estimated that each undercounted person costs his or her municipality ,000 in federal resources.” Funding for public schools would reportedly be severely hit by such cuts in federal funding.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: 3) Global Conflicts: In his three years in office, Trump has escalated tensions with numerous powers, China and Iran in particular.

topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: In the period leading up to the global spread of the virus, China had already taken on special enemy status.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: In January, the president imposed yet more tariffs on that country’s products while sanctions on 70 billion worth of Chinese imports were left in place even though his administration claimed to have successfully concluded what he called “phase one” of a future trade deal .

topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Congress then passed a law aimed at preventing the president from further attacks on Iran without its approval.

text: And there are reports of more to come from his administration.

topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Meanwhile, inquiries into Trump’s political misdeeds have also been put on hold due to the pandemic.

topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Bottom line, the investigations and proceedings against Trump, personal and presidential, are on hold for the foreseeable future.

topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: As the 2016 campaign played out, for instance, he was already expressing his fears of a “rigged election.” He accused the media of misreporting and twisting the preferences of voters in support of Hillary Clinton, while later claiming her campaign had meddled in the election process.

text: Democratic governors are largely leading the fight against COVID-19 — while Republicans fall behind – Alternet.org.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: by Luke Fowler , Boise State University ; Jaclyn Kettler , Boise State University , and Stephanie Witt , Boise State University.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: While the coronavirus pandemic is a national and international concern, state and local officials find themselves on the front lines of the public health battle.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Governors, in particular, have been in the spotlight in recent weeks.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: New York’s Andrew Cuomo has been praised by news outlets for his leadership at the epicenter of the U.S. outbreak, while others have been criticized for slow responses.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: A clear partisan gap has emerged in how quickly governors have declared emergencies and issue stay-at-home orders.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Democratic governors have issued orders three to four days sooner than Republican governors, on average.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: We study state governments, including their interactions with the federal government.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Our previous work on federalism and state politics has identified partisan conflict between national, state and local government .
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Federalism is the distribution of power and authority across levels of government, and partisan conflict involves disagreements and competition between political parties.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Partisan conflict over policy is nothing new.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: But the covid-19 has put some governors in an ideologically compromising position because Republicans, who traditionally advocated for states’ rights, now find themselves deferring to the federal government and Democrats are leading the nation on pandemic responses and reaping the political rewards .
label: Argument_against
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: They are also pushing for more federal coordination efforts, especially in obtaining high-demand medical supplies .
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Earlier emergency declarations and stay-at-home orders increase the chances of a better outcome for the health of people in the state.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Based on a review of emergency declarations, we found that the median date for instituting a state of emergency for Democratic governors was March 10, and for Republican governors, March 13.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Although stay-at-home orders have only been issued in 41 states as of April 4, a similar trend is emerging there.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: So far, all 24 Democratic governors have issued such an order with a median date of March 24.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: On the other hand, only 17 of 26 Republican governors have, and of those the median date is March 30.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Some argue that states led by Republicans were hit by COVID-19 later or not as hard as states led by Democrats.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Yet based on data from the COVID Tracking Project , there was little difference in the number of cases in each state when governors announced these orders.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Most governors used boilerplate language citing public health experts in their announcements.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: But some evidence shows that Republican governors were responding to leadership from President Donald Trump, who largely downplayed the severity of the pandemic for weeks, which discouraged governors from taking actions that contradicted the leader of their party.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: For instance , on March 7, he said “I’m not concerned at all,” and on March 10 he claimed “it will go away.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Just stay calm.”.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Additionally, nearly half of Republican governors declared emergencies on the same day – March 13 – that the president declared a national emergency, and a few have explicitly cited Trump as a reason behind their decisions.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Georgia Republican Gov.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Brian Kemp said, “Based on President Trump’s emergency declaration, I will declare a public health emergency.”.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Florida’s Ron DeSantis, a Republican who had resisted issuing a stay-at-home order despite mounting pressure from public health officials and the media, cited the shift in Trump’s tone and demeanor as the signal it was time to issue a stay-at-home order to contain the pandemic in his state.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Other Republican governors acted earlier.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: One factor in those cases is Trump’s approval ratings: Republicans in states where the president is unpopular moved more quickly .
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Trump’s net approval – the portion of survey respondents approving of Trump’s job performance minus the portion disapproving –.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: in states with Republican governors that declared emergencies before March 13 averages  1; in Republican states declaring emergencies on or after March 13, it averages  8.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: For Democratic states, Trump’s net approval averages -9 before March 13, and -10 on or after March 13.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Clearly, Trump’s net approval is important to the Republican governors.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Ohio’s Mike DeWine was the first governor to call for a statewide closure of schools on March 12, and Maryland’s Larry Hogan , who has been vocal in criticizing the White House’s leadership, was the first Republican governor to declare an emergency, on March 5.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Trump’s net approval in Ohio is 0 and in Maryland, -24.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: In contrast, Democratic governors have advocated for more aggressive response efforts at both state and federal levels.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: In addition to Andrew Cuomo, who has become a key figure in recent weeks, Michigan’s Gretchen Whitmer has traded jabs with the president.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: New Jersey’s Phil Murphy has called for a “postmortem” on the federal response to understand why it has gone so wrong.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: While conflict between political parties is usually most visible in Congress, the covid-19 has put partisan conflict between the president and governors on full display as federal and state governments try to contain this pandemic.
label: Argument_for
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Wuhan Coronavirus Must Be Our Sputnik Moment With China - American Greatness.
label: Argument_against
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Back then, it seemed to make sense.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: We were in a Cold War that easily could have turned hot and taken all our lives.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Of course, it’s easy to forget that we had 25,000 nuclear warheads aimed at each other across the East-West divide.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: So if America could cultivate dissension and sow division between the two biggest Communist dictatorships, and so weaken the “Second World,” so much the better.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: That was how Henry Kissinger sold President Nixon the idea of cozying up to the Chinese Communists.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: After 25 years of nonrecognition and isolation, an American president wasn’t simply going to reestablish perfunctory ties with Beijing, but instead, he spent a whole week in China as a part of normalizing relations with the dictatorship.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: At a time when the main threat to us was the continued global spread of Communism and nuclear war with the dictatorship in Moscow, such a move had a quality of intuitive seduction.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Yet Kissinger’s idea of weakening the “Socialist International” by driving a wedge between Beijing and Moscow broke one of the cardinal rules of good strategy: it is never wise to empower one enemy simply for the sake of weakening another, more proximate one.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Nixon’s fatal acquiescence to the plan to lure China away from Moscow led to Beijing’s playing America—and the West—like a cheap fiddle in the decades that followed.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: With the geopolitical door opened by a president who had earned his anti-Communist credentials after World War II on the House Un-American Activities Committee, Beijing realized a dream come true.
label: NoArgument
topic: the impact of covid-19 is risible

text: Researchers Claim To Develop Universal Flu Vaccine… – 1AFSYM.
label: Argument_for

text: CBS Local — As Americans deal with a devastating flu season that has already claimed hundreds of lives, researchers at Georgia State University claim they’ve developed a way to produce a “universal flu vaccine” that could protect patients for several years with just one shot.
label: Argument_for

text: Dr. Lei Deng and Dr. Baozhong Wang say that a new approach of using double-layered protein nanoparticles to target the influenza virus produced a longer lasting immunity to the flu in mice.
label: Argument_for

text: “We’re trying to develop a new vaccine approach that eliminates the need for vaccination every year,” Dr. Wang, an associate professor at Georgia State, said in a press release .
label: Argument_for

text: “You wouldn’t need to change the vaccine type every year because it’s universal and can protect against any influenza virus.”.
label: Argument_for

text: The researchers say the yearly flu shot targets protein “heads” that attack the body and make people feel sick.
label: Argument_against

text: The problem with those shots is that scientists make the annual injection so hyper-focused on killing one particular strain of the flu that the vaccines become fairly useless once these protein heads mutate.
label: Argument_against

text: “This vaccine is composed of very conserved domains.
label: NoArgument

text: That’s the reason why the induced immunity can offer universal protection,” Dr. Deng explains.
label: Argument_for

text: Georgia State is now looking to move their tests of the nanoparticle vaccine on to ferrets, who have a similar respiratory system to humans.
label: NoArgument

text: The CDC says the current flu vaccine in the U.S. has a success rate of around 40 percent.
label: Argument_for

text: A similar injection in Australia reportedly prevented the flu in just 10 percent of patients during their flu season.
label: Argument_against

text: MEDIA IDENTITY CRISIS GROWS – 1AFSYM.
label: NoArgument

text: London (AFP) – Trolling, impersonating, demonising: these are just some of the behaviours encouraged in a new online game launching Tuesday in which young players become "fake news tycoons" — to counter growing misinformation.
label: NoArgument

text: Researchers at Cambridge University have teamed up with a Dutch media collective to develop an English version of the game aimed at inoculating people against the spread of so-called fake news.
label: NoArgument

text: The exercise encourages participants, who are tasked with building audiences for their imaginary fake news sites, to stoke fear, anger and mistrust by simulating the manipulation of online content.
label: NoArgument

text: In the game they choose polarising falsehoods to publish, cultivate an army of Twitter bots, fabricate evidence, and propagate dubious articles and conspiracy theories.
label: NoArgument

text: "If you know what it is like to walk in the shoes of someone who is actively trying to deceive you, it should increase your ability to spot and resist the techniques of deceit," said Sander Van Der Linden, director of the university’s Social Decision-Making Lab.
label: NoArgument

text: The psychological theory behind the effort is called "inoculation".
label: NoArgument

text: Researchers at Cambridge last year found that briefly exposing people to tactics used by fake news producers can act as a "psychological vaccine" against bogus anti-science campaigns.
label: NoArgument

text: A pilot study conducted with teenagers in a Dutch high school used an early paper-and-pen trial of the online game, and showed the perceived "reliability" of fake news to be diminished in teens that played compared to a control group.
label: NoArgument

text: "A biological vaccine administers a small dose of the disease to build immunity," said Van Der Linden.
label: Argument_for

text: "Similarly, inoculation theory suggests that exposure to a weak or demystified version of an argument makes it easier to refute when confronted with more persuasive claims."
label: NoArgument

text: The game, based in part on existing studies of online disinformation, takes its cues from actual conspiracy theories about organisations such as the United Nations, and about issues such as vaccines.
label: NoArgument

text: It is set to be translated for countries such as Ukraine, where disinformation campaigns are particularly rife.
label: NoArgument

text: WORST FLU IN 13 YEARS – 1AFSYM.
label: NoArgument

text: HealthFlu season is shaping up as one of the worst in years, officials say.
label: NoArgument

text: A patient recovers from the flu at the Palomar Medical Center in Escondido, Calif. Gregory Bull/AP.
label: NoArgument

text: he entire continental United States is experiencing widespread flu right now, the first time in the 13 years of the current tracking system that that has happened, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
label: NoArgument

text: Officials said that this flu season is shaping up to be one of the worst in recent years.
label: NoArgument

text: The rate of flu hospitalizations — the number of people hospitalized with flu per 100,000 — nearly doubled last week compared with the previous week.
label: NoArgument

text: Last week it was 22.7 per 100,000 people; the week before that rate was 13.7.
label: NoArgument

text: At the peak of the 2014-15 season, one of the two most severe seasons in the last 15 years or so, 29.9 people out of every 100,000 were hospitalized for flu.
label: NoArgument

text: Related Story: ‘The problem child of seasonal flu’: Beware this winter’s virus.
label: NoArgument

text: The latest data — for the week ending Jan. 6 — suggest the season may be peaking right now, the CDC’s director, Dr. Brenda Fitzgerald, told reporters Friday.
label: NoArgument

text: But she warned that many more people will be infected before the season is over.
label: NoArgument

text: There’s a difference between an active flu season — when a large number of people get sick — and a severe season, when the numbers of people hospitalized for flu or who die from the infection are unusually high.
label: NoArgument

text: It can be hard to tell in real time where a flu season will fall on the severity scale, because sometimes reports of influenza hospitalization and deaths — especially deaths among children — lag.
label: NoArgument

text: That said, this year is starting to look like a severe season, and maybe more severe than last year, which was also bad, said Dr. Dan Jernigan, head of CDC’s influenza division.
label: NoArgument

text: “There’s lots of flu in lots of places,” he said.
label: NoArgument

text: So far, Jernigan said, this year’s season doesn’t appear to be quite as bad as 2014-15.
label: NoArgument

text: The influenza A virus H3N2 has caused the lion’s share of the illness in most parts of the country this year.
label: NoArgument

text: But recently there’s been an uptick in activity by another influenza A virus, H1N1, Jernigan said, warning that even if the season appears to have peaked, flu viruses will circulate for weeks to come and people should continue to take precautions against getting infected.
label: NoArgument

text: Jernigan said that people over the age of 65 are being hospitalized for flu this season more than any other population.
label: NoArgument

text: Even people age 50 to 64 are being hospitalized in high numbers.
label: NoArgument

text: Popular Now!
label: NoArgument

text: ‘The problem child of seasonal flu’: Beware this winter’s virus.
label: NoArgument

text: Flu often hits the ends of the age spectrum more than the middle, and that’s the case this year as well.
label: NoArgument

text: The CDC reported seven more children have died from flu, bringing the season total to 20 so far.
label: NoArgument

text: While tragic, that number is low in comparison with other years — 110 last year, 92 in 2015-2016.
label: NoArgument

text: But if other seasons are a gauge, that grim tally may continue to rise in coming weeks.
label: NoArgument

text: Officials feared that the flu vaccine may not work particularly well this season, but it appears to be faring slightly better than expected.
label: Argument_for

text: Preliminary testing by the CDC suggests the vaccine is probably more protective than it was in Australia during its 2017 winter.
label: Argument_for

text: The Australian interim estimate suggested the H3N2 component of the vaccine — and H3N2 was the main virus there during their most recent winter — was only about 10 percent effective.
label: Argument_against

text: That means if 100 people got the flu shot and all were exposed to H3N2 viruses, 10 would have been protected.
label: Argument_for

text: Jernigan said it looks more like the H3N2 portion of the vaccine is performing here like it did last year, when it was 34 percent effective at preventing infection.
label: Argument_for

text: Unfortunately, that’s about on par for the flu shot’s H3N2 component, which is the weak link of flu vaccine.
label: NoArgument

text: The CDC should have interim data on the question of the vaccine’s effectiveness in the second half of February.

text: Vaccines Covered In Republican Presidential Debate - Exposes Candidates’ Concern Over “Too Many Too Soon” - AGE OF AUTISM.
label: NoArgument

text: From Canary Party: Last night’s Republican Presidential Debate featured a discussion on vaccination in light of the Disneyland measles outbreak that went differently than the debate moderators anticipated.
label: NoArgument

text: A question was posed to Dr. Ben Carson asking if Donald Trump should stop linking childhood vaccinations to autism.
label: Argument_against

text: In the discussion that followed, Dr. Carson made the following statement, “….It is true that we are probably giving way too many in too short a period of time.
label: NoArgument

text: And a lot of pediatricians now recognize that, and, I think, are cutting down on the number and the proximity in which those are done, and I think that's appropriate.”
label: NoArgument

text: Donald Trump added to the conversation that autism has become an epidemic and “has gotten totally out of control.”
label: NoArgument

text: Mr. Trump then advocated for smaller doses of vaccines over a longer a period of time.
label: NoArgument

text: Senator Rand Paul also chimed in, “I'm all for vaccines.
label: NoArgument

text: But I'm also for freedom.
label: NoArgument

text: I'm also a little concerned about how they're bunched up.
label: NoArgument

text: My kids had all of their vaccines, and even if the science doesn't say bunching them up is a problem, I ought to have the right to spread my vaccines out a little bit at the very least.”
label: Argument_for

text: The Canary Party thanks these three brave candidates, two of whom are physicians, for having an honest conversation about vaccination.
label: NoArgument

text: We are especially grateful for their recognition that our country has an vaccination schedule that many parents see as too aggressive and rigid.
label: Argument_against

text: In the inevitable, post-debate commentary, many pundits have attacked the candidates for their remarks, repeating the tired claims that all connections between autism and vaccines have been “discredited.”
label: Argument_for

text: None of these pundits acknowledge the admissions of fraud by a CDC insider that have discredited the government-funded studies that have fed the propaganda campaigns in defense of the federally-protected vaccine program.
label: NoArgument

text: Dr. William Thompson, a vaccine safety analyst at the CDC, admitted that he and his co-authors “omitted statistically significant information” in a 2004 study that would have associated the MMR vaccine with autism.
label: NoArgument

text: Instead, they published a paper in 2004 that exonerated MMR and held a secret meeting in order to destroy the evidence of fraud.
label: NoArgument

text: Another CDC-funded researcher, Dr. Poul Thorsen, participated in several of the studies that found no role for vaccines in autism and is currently on the Office of Inspector General’s “Most Wanted” list for fraud.
label: NoArgument

text: Contrary to what is widely reported in the media, and by the former pharmaceutical executives at Autism Speaks, there is a great deal of research that does link vaccines and autism and explores the mechanisms by which this process can happen.
label: Argument_against

text: We urge all candidates in the presidential election to review the research for themselves.
label: NoArgument

label: NoArgument

label: NoArgument

text: Inside Harjallah IDP camp, close to Eastern Ghouta.
label: NoArgument

text: 20,000 Syrian civilians have been rehomed here (temporarily) from Eastern Ghouta including Douma.
label: NoArgument

text: They are provided with food, housing, cleaning materials, water and electricity by the Syrian government and a number of Syrian NGOs.
label: NoArgument

text: When I was in Eastern Ghouta during the last moments of final liberation, particularly for Jaish Al Islam occupied Douma, I witnessed the exodus of civilians from their incarceration by Western financed extremist groups of all denominations.
label: NoArgument

text: These exhausted, traumatised citizens of the eastern suburbs and countryside of Damascus exited via the Syrian government and Russian protected Humanitarian corridors that enabled them to escape despite harrowing tales of being shelled and sniped by terrorist factions, infuriated by their departure.
label: NoArgument

text: I was able to interview a number of these people who had fled the unbelievable deprivation and brutality of these extremist “regimes” that were imposed upon them by the Syrian regime-change-war proponents in the West.
label: NoArgument

text: Their testimonies lay waste to the myths of these mercenaries and armed militia groups being freedom bringers or champions of “Democracy”.
label: NoArgument

text: They detail a life of fear, poverty, homelessness and hunger beyond the realms of understanding for many in the West who have been duped into believing the “moderate” myths promulgated by state media outlets in the UK, EU and US – nothing more than a glorified protection racket for the criminal NATO member state foreign policy targeting Syria.
label: NoArgument

text: Corporate media will naturally throw its collective hands up in horror at the Pandora’s box of secrets that is opened by the voices of these Syrian people who are finally able to speak freely without fear of retribution from the ruling extremist mafia gangs that held them hostage for 6 years in Eastern Ghouta.
label: NoArgument

text: These corporate media stenographers will claim these Syrians only speak out of fear of Syrian Government punishment if they were to express views that were against their government.
label: NoArgument

text: The group-Think Tanks will also denigrate these Syrian civilians, dismissing their words as “carefully selected” condemnation of the atrocities committed by the extremist groups those Atlanticist institutions have promoted and supported throughout the 7 year proxy war.
label: NoArgument

text: Will these “experts” and “analysts” have the moral decreptitude to condemn all civilian testimony from within the 85% of inhabited Syrian territory under Syrian government protection as scripted by Syrian government officials?
label: NoArgument

text: Testimony is always open to interpretation and requires back-up investigations and empirical evidence but to dismiss this civilian testimony outright is an insult to these people who have endured appalling cruelty and miserable conditions for so many years.
label: NoArgument

text: They have a right to speak, they have a right to be heard and their testimony should be taken into consideration when evaluating the events inside Syria that have been woefully misrepresented by the Western media bias in favour of a regime change narrative serving the neocon war hawks in Washington, London and Paris.
label: NoArgument

text: How many “anonymous” sources have western media cited to support their claims against the Syrian government, Syrian Arab Army and allies?

text: How many questionable, terrorist affiliated witnesses and western financed shadow state organisations do these media outlets rely upon to provide the narratives that fit into their narrow framework?

text: How many of these western media sideline hecklers have actually been to Syria and confronted these Syrian people with their ‘suspicions’ that they are lying or are speaking under duress?

text: The interviews I conducted and have uploaded to my YouTube channel are on the whole unedited.

text: They are the unadulterated accounts of life under Jaish Al Islam rule or an assortment of other groups such as Failaq Al Rahman, Ahrar Al Sham, Nusra Front (Al Qaeda).

text: They also contain very clear accusations levied at the NATO-member-state financed and promoted White Helmets – accusations that echo those made by Syrian civilians liberated from a Nusra Front dominated occupation of the Eastern districts of Aleppo in December 2016.

label: NoArgument

text: Her name is Sabah Al Mushref.
label: NoArgument

text: She spoke to me for some time and I will upload the videos and her testimony bit by bit as it is both harrowing and powerful.

label: NoArgument

text: We had no government officials with us during the interview.

label: NoArgument

text: As I have mentioned, corporate media “journalists” love to discredit these testimonies as being ‘influenced’ by the Syrian government but I challenge those armchair “experts” to come to Syria and to tell Sabah she is not telling the truth.
label: NoArgument

text: Have these people not suffered enough at the hands of the terrorist groups that the same corporate media in the West describe as “freedom and democracy rebels”?
label: NoArgument

text: These women have escaped a fate that was ‘worth than death’ for them.
label: NoArgument

text: Many of these civilians described the multiple “deaths” they experienced living in extremist-occupied Eastern Ghouta.
label: NoArgument

text: These women were still exhausted and sick but they are safe and life can begin again without the ghosts of death, child abduction, organ theft and torture that haunt them.
label: NoArgument

text: This lady clung to her child and told me she had been so frightened for her safety, so many had been “stolen” for organ theft, some just disappeared and were never heard of again.
label: NoArgument

text: I will be bringing you more from this Syrian heroine as I receive updated translation of her testimony she represents all who have suffered under Western backed terrorist rule and who have been liberated by the Syrian Arab Army and their allies the future is not easy, there is another war to be fought as many Syrians told me, “The war of forgiveness” – but when we see the spirit, the courage of these women and many of the most vulnerable of Syrian society who have endured a life of deprivation, fear and oppression, yet escaped intact and determined to rebuild, to restore and to lead their lives in a Syria free from terrorismwe know that for all of us, the battle is one for justice and freedom for all honourable, true human beings.

text: “White Helmets stole everything”.
label: Argument_against

text: Maan Qseedeh , 23 years old, a resident of Jisreen.
label: NoArgument

text: Full Transcript of Testimony:.
label: NoArgument

text: “We were in our land, farming, working and everything was good, then people from Al-Rahman Brigade and white helmets showed up.
label: NoArgument

text: They kicked us out of our lands, and they took everything from us, even our money, and they kept us imprisoned in the town.We stayed there for a while, then terrorist gangs came and took us to Hazzeh, where we stayed for 2 or 3 days, near al Mahmoud mosque.
label: NoArgument

text: Then at night, they told us we were going to be hit by chemical weapons and told us to be cautious.
label: NoArgument

text: And then they – white helmets- hit us with chemical weapons, they hit us with poisonous gases.
label: Argument_against

text: We put on some home-made masks.
label: NoArgument

text: My family and I went upstairs, we stayed for 2 days, then we went back to Jisreen, we stayed there at our relatives’ and the terrorist groups came and told us that the Syrian Arab Army was at the outskirts of Jisreen.
label: NoArgument

text: They told us they were going to take all young men to Ain-Tarma, and we had a fight with them.
label: NoArgument

text: The army had sent word for us to raise white flags or Syrian flags so they would come to us and help us.
label: NoArgument

text: So the terrorists tried to occupy the buildings, and we ganged up on them and kicked them out.
label: NoArgument

text: Later, around dusk, a man came demanding all families and residents to move with him to Ain-Tarma, and he said it was forbidden to anybody to leave with the Syrian Arab Army.
label: NoArgument

text: A guy left the shelter, and they asked him where he was going, he said he wanted to turn himself in to the Syrian Arab Army, so they shot him, and they did not let anyone pick him up, and told us not to pick him up until he (the man) would come back, then they left.
label: NoArgument

text: After they left, a group of our elders raised white flags and walked towards the Syrian Arab Army area, and explained to them what was going on, so they came to us, and got us out and we’re very good.”.
label: NoArgument

text: Living in fear of child abduction.
label: NoArgument

text: Question: When you decided to leave the area, were you afraid for the lives of your children?
label: NoArgument

text: Full Transcript of Testimony:.
label: NoArgument

text: “Of course, I was, we were already scared when we were inside, we didn’t have the nerve to even go out the door, we stayed for nearly 20 days, without food, or water, no bath.
label: NoArgument

text: This little girl almost died, she was dehydrated, there was no one to help us there, over there, if you know one of them, they’d feed you, if not, then you’d starve.
label: NoArgument

text: We were strangers, we are from Marj Al-Sultan (an area near the Airport), and we sought shelter in Zamalka and Hamourya.
label: NoArgument

text: So those in charge of those towns treated us badly.
label: NoArgument

text: They would feed the people of their town, but not us.
label: NoArgument

text: and they would tell us to go see the representative of our town, which didn’t exist.
label: NoArgument

text: We had some sheep back then, and they were stolen from us in Madyara.
label: NoArgument

text: They would attack families, and steal everything, sheep, cars, motorbikes, even batteries.
label: NoArgument

text: We ran from Madyara to Nashabiyeh, and it was the same thing, they kidnapped children, and stole organs.
label: NoArgument

text: In the last days we were almost dead, So we decided to take the risk, and die once if we had to, instead of dying of hunger, and dying from fear.
label: NoArgument

text: Kids being kidnapped, you watch your kids suffer in front of you.
label: NoArgument

text: We were denied of everything, even Barley bread, we couldn’t get it, it was 2400 Syrian Pounds for 1 kilo, they just made it a trade.
label: NoArgument

text: One kilo of cord reached 2000 Syrian pounds, Sugar reached 6000 or 7000 Syrian pounds.
label: NoArgument

text: So, we started using the Diabetic sugar (saccharine) and my chidlren got sick.
label: NoArgument

text: This little girl got sick and I took her to Douma, and Jaish Al-Islam told me treatment was only for people of Douma.
label: NoArgument

text: Nobody would help us, in the hospitals they wouldn’t even treat us, they would barely provide the basics and kick the kids out.”.
label: NoArgument

text: Civilians used as human shields by Jaish al Islam.
label: NoArgument

text: Question: I’m going to ask you a very important question, how did you feel and what was your impression when terrorist groups took over your areas, what did you think?
label: NoArgument

text: Full Transcript of Testimony:.
label: NoArgument

text: “We did not feel comfortable about them, we wanted to get out but they would threaten us, anybody who wanted to leave was to be slaughtered, they said the army was going to slaughter us.
label: NoArgument

text: So, the men feared for their lives and stayed inside, women too, we were told we’d be slaughtered because we were from Ghouta, we couldn’t leave, they told us it would be safer for us to stay, So we waited for a solution, and it never came, and things would just get worse, then they didn’t allow us to leave the area.
label: NoArgument

text: If we wanted to leave through Wafideen camp, or Jisreen, Jaish Al-Islam wouldn’t let us, wherever we wanted to go they would just push us deeper into their territories, to use us as human shields.
label: NoArgument

text: When the people found out that it was just getting even worse, and we were so afraid to even walk in the streets, and the death of a person became something very normal – they decided they decided to risk being “killed” by the Syrian Army and they just wanted to be let out.
label: NoArgument

text: That’s how they finally got the courage to demand to leave the area, when they saw how men, women and children were dying, they decided to leave the area, even if they were going to die, their children at least would live safely.
label: NoArgument

text: When they got out and found out nobody was going to kill them, they encouraged the people who remained inside to leave the area as well.”.
label: NoArgument

text: White Helmets staged ‘chemical attacks’.
label: Argument_against

text: “The White Helmets had workshops where they would burn plastic in 1000 litre tanks until the tanks exploded showering civilians with molten plastic.
label: Argument_against

text: The White Helmets would use the burned victims and dead civilians to claim the “Syrian Arab Army” had attacked us with “chemical weapons”.
label: Argument_against

text: Full transcript of testimony:.
label: NoArgument

text: “The White Helmets had workshops producing plastic materials that had a smell similar to chemical gases, a suffocating smell.
label: Argument_against

text: If you burn any piece of plastic, you can’t stand there and smell it, it will cause you to suffocate quickly.
label: NoArgument

text: The White Helmets did that a lot in Ghouta, they made a lot of them, they’d put 5 barrels in each workshop, filling it with lots of plastic, and then they would put it on a strong fire, claiming they are trying to extract diesel and Gas from plastic, while it contained some materials that had a smell similar to chemical weapons.
label: Argument_against

text: Those barrels/tanks would explode, I’ve seen many tanks explode with my own eyes.
label: NoArgument

text: I still know exactly where they are located.
label: NoArgument

text: If I can take you to Ghouta, I can show you the area where the tanks are.
label: NoArgument

text: The ones that exploded and killed people.
label: NoArgument

text: I was in my car, when the tank exploded, while I was driving about 150 meters away from it.
label: NoArgument

text: I watched it from the car window, the tank was a big fire ball, a 1000 litre tank full of plastic.
label: NoArgument

text: It flew up, and fell in pieces, burning plastic, those pieces would land on people, some were burned to death, some burned but didn’t die.
label: NoArgument

text: 1.5 hours later we heard on the news that the “Syrian Arab Army had hit Ghouta with chemical weapons in Hamouryeh”.
label: NoArgument

text: I saw that with my own eyes, and the area is still there, I can take you there and show you where it happened, those tanks that exploded are still there.
label: NoArgument

text: Until now, at the first turn in Beit Sawa, between Hamouryeh, Bait Sawa and Ashaari land, there’s an alley, that’s where the tanks are hidden, and on the right hand you can find the workshops.
label: NoArgument

text: that’s how they (White Helmets) produced something similar to Chemical weapons.
label: NoArgument

text: When 30-40 people would die, they would tell you that the “Syrian Arab Army hit Ghouta with chemical weapons”.
label: NoArgument

text: While we knew what happened, we couldn’t say a word.
label: NoArgument

text: He (White Helmet) almost opened fire at me when I slowed down after I saw the tank explode.
label: NoArgument

text: He told me to go, it was none of my business.
label: NoArgument

text: I told him people were burning, he yelled at me, threatened to shoot me, so I just took off quickly, and not just me, there were many people like me, nobody dared to stop, until they finished their scene.
label: NoArgument

text: Those who were burned, those who were maimed, and those who died – hours later, or the next day, you’d see them on the news saying that “Eastern Ghouta had been hit by chemical weapons”.
label: NoArgument

text: It wasn’t ‘chemical weapons’, the workshops are still there, White helmets would take plastic and diesel and make the tanks explode, to terrorise and kill people, so the western countries would believe that it was a chemical weapon hit, while they – the western countries – produce the actual chemical weapons.”.
label: Argument_against

text: White Helmets left civilians to die.
label: Argument_against

text: Full Transcript of Testimony:.
label: NoArgument

text: “Civil defence” (White Helmets) were supposed to help wounded civilians, but NO!
label: Argument_against

text: if any of the terrorists were wounded they would run to their aid, but civilians – NO.
label: NoArgument

text: It was very rare, if they (White Helmets) weren’t going to film it, they wouldn’t come.
label: NoArgument

text: When the camera was there they would run around as if they were helping people.
label: NoArgument

text: Our neighbor in Zamalka – we left on Friday, but on the Previous Wednesday, there were strikes.
label: NoArgument

text: The ceiling collapsed onto the woman, and her children.
label: NoArgument

text: We – the women – pulled 3 kids from under the wreckage, they were alive, but the mother remained there, from the morning till the evening.
label: NoArgument

text: Nobody came to help.
label: NoArgument

text: We witnessed that.
label: NoArgument

text: Her husband kept running around asking them for help, they said “NO”.
label: NoArgument

text: They (White Helmets) blamed us for leaving the basement.
label: NoArgument

text: We were dying in these basements.
label: NoArgument

text: The smell, alone, could kill you.
label: NoArgument

text: We were sitting on the floor, nothing there, not even toilets, we needed water, they had given us water tanks with taps, but when the taps were broken, they didn’t fix them.
label: NoArgument

text: We had to go far away to find water.
label: NoArgument

text: When the woman was trapped under the ceiling, they (White Helmets) didn’t come to help her.
label: NoArgument

text: She stayed there till it was a bit before dusk when groups of people came and got her outin pieces.”.
label: NoArgument

text: “We raised the Syrian flag and we were targeted for our loyalty to the Syrian state and Army”.
label: NoArgument

text: Mohammed is a father and grandfather.
label: NoArgument

text: During the time I interviewed his sons and relatives who had gathered around his bed to talk to me, he was in clear pain from the wound to his leg.
label: NoArgument

text: He told me that on the 6th March 2018 he and his family defied the Failaq Al Rahman terrorists and raised the Syrian flag in Hamouriyah in support of the Syrian Arab Army that was closing in on the armed groups in this district.
label: NoArgument

text: That evening armed members of Failaq Al Rahman (FAR) came to Mohammed’s house.
label: NoArgument

text: He told his sons to leave as he feared for their lives.
label: NoArgument

text: “I told them they (militants) would not.
label: NoArgument

text: While thousands of humanitarian organisations around the world are struggling fiercely with diminishing support from governments and the public, one has achieved a surprising amount of support from Western governments in a surprisingly short period of time and gained a surprising attention from mainstream media and ditto political elites: The Syrian Civil Defence or White Helmets.
label: NoArgument

text: Their name of course makes you think of the UN’s Blue Helmet and white is the colour of those who should be protected in harm’s way – and the colour of innocence.
label: NoArgument

text: However, for many years there has been an Argentinian relief organisation with the same name.
label: NoArgument

text: The SCD or White Helmets counts nearly 3.000 rescue workers who operate in very dangerous areas in rebel-held territories in Syria and claims that it has, in three years, rescued about 70.000 lives according to its Twitter account (or 65 per day).
label: Argument_for

text: Contrary to what you might think, it isn’t a Syrian organisation because Syria has its own organisation, incidentally also called Syria Civil Defence, which was established in 1953 and is registered with ICDO, the International Civil Defence Organisation , since 1972.
label: NoArgument

text: The White Helmets seems to have an annual budget of US$ 30 million and has raised a total support of well over US$ 100 million.
label: NoArgument

text: And it seems that they operate exclusively in war zones in which the fighting against the Syrian government and the Syrian Arab Army takes place, i.e. in ‘liberated’ areas where hundreds of groups and some 80 countries, mainly NATO members, Gulf states and Saudi-Arabia, operate.
label: NoArgument

text: On the White Helmets’ briefing page it is stated that “funding for their humanitarian relief work is received from the aid budgets of Japan, Denmark, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and the United States.”.
label: NoArgument

text: Here is how the Foreign Ministry in Copenhagen explains the roughly US$ 9 million to the White helmets from Denmark, a country that bombs in both Iraq and Syria.
label: NoArgument

text: Other civil society and humanitarian organisations inside Syria have not been so fortunate.
label: NoArgument

text: You’ve probably not heard that much about the Syrian Arab Red Crescent and its work ?
label: NoArgument

text: How much/little support have they received from Western humanitarian-concerned governments?
label: NoArgument

text: And in general, civil society organisations in Syria – women, peace, human rights, culture, etc. – have received nothing like US$ 100 million in a few years and no one has such a flashy media appearance as the White Helmets.
label: NoArgument

text: Photo from the White Helmets’ homepage.
label: NoArgument

text: The White Helmets was started in 2013 by James Le Mesurier who seems to have tried a little of everything everywhere, including the grey zones of special forces and intelligence in virtually all NATO wars, Yugoslavia in particular.
label: NoArgument

text: He later set up a foundation in Holland to gather the funds.
label: NoArgument

text: Here is a recent account by Scott Ritter , former US Marine Corps intelligence officer and weapons inspector in Iraq with tremendous knowledge of things Middle East:.
label: NoArgument

text: “ The organizational underpinnings of the White Helmets can be sourced to a March 2013 meeting in Istanbul between a retired British military officer, James Le Mesurier—who had experience in the murky world of private security companies and the shadowy confluence between national security and intelligence operations and international organizations—and representatives of the Syrian National Council (SNC) and the Qatari Red Crescent Society.
label: NoArgument

text: Earlier that month, the SNC was given Syria’s seat in the Arab League at a meeting of the league held in Qatar.
label: NoArgument

text: At that meeting, the SNC assumed Syria’s seat, and the Arab League authorized member states to actively provide support, including arms and ammunition, to the Syrian rebels.
label: NoArgument

text: The Qataris, working through the SNC, helped assemble for Le Mesurier $300,000 in seed money from Japan, the United States and the United Kingdom for a seven-day course designed to train and equip a 25-person rescue team, recruited by the SNC, for duty in so-called “liberated areas” of Syria.
label: NoArgument

text: The SNC made available a pair of Syrian activists—Raed Saleh and Farouq Habib—to assist Le Mesurier in this work.”.
label: NoArgument

text: The group is – as will be seen below – treated as uncontroversial in virtually all Western mainstream media.
label: NoArgument

text: However, there is enough material with documentation to merit caution.
label: NoArgument

text: If you read media reports about the White Helmets and do not see the author mention that this group’s real identity is disputed and functions controversial you can be sure that you are wasting your time with somebody who is politically incredibly naive, or gullible; someone who has not done his or her research or is knowingly part of a deceptive effort serving a one-sided political agenda.
label: Argument_against

text: The White Helmets definitely is an controversial NGO – at the same time as it is (made) difficult to understand clearly what it really is.
label: NoArgument

text: And until the whole picture has been developed, anyone ought to be cautious with taking information about them at face value.
label: NoArgument

text: So much must be clear given the links below.
label: NoArgument

text: That said, this author has not been on the ground but has studied both the pro- et contra links provided below.
label: NoArgument

text: Some observers draw the conclusion that the White Helmets are purely good guys rescuing lots of people, children in particular.
label: Argument_for

text: The opposite advocacy claims that, all told, White helmets are part of the terrorist groups, serve Western governments with intelligence and that their backers run political propaganda in their name and that they are simply executioners – murderers with a human face.
label: Argument_against

text: But does it have to be either/or?
label: NoArgument

text: An alternative hypothesis could be that the White Helmets is a dual-purpose organisation.
label: NoArgument

text: They claim to be ordinary Syrian volunteers who came together around the idea of saving lives and are truly altruistic “bakers, tailors, engineers, pharmacists, painters, carpenters, students and many more, the White Helmets are volunteers from all walks of life.”
label: Argument_for

text: It could well be that some of them actually are, even a majority.
label: NoArgument

text: That doesn’t preclude that other elements – not the least those operating outside Syria such as foundations, PR and marketing firms, change organisations, NATO government and NGOs are in it with less noble, war-promoting purposes.
label: Argument_against

text: Find below a link collection – long but fascinating in its wealth of information.
label: NoArgument

text: We bring it as a help to those seriously interested in Syria’s fate and in studying how opinions are being built by means of connected actors in a rather opaque networking structure, in how NGOs have increasingly become Near -governmental organisations and for those who do not want to sound foolish when they discuss these matters.
label: NoArgument

text: First some links to how the the White Helmets presents themselves.

text: Dr. Papadopoulos’ interest in Syria, which would eventually lead him to a passion for the country, emerged in August 1991, when he was on holiday with my family in Cyprus.
label: NoArgument

text: His Father was telling him that Syria was ready to go to war with Turkey as a result of Turkish threats to restrict the flow of water running into Syria from the Euphrates.
label: NoArgument

text: He told him that Syria had long supported Cyprus against Turkey and that the Syrians had a very close relationship with Russia, or the Soviet Union, as it was then.
label: NoArgument

text: His Father added to the point about the Syrian-Russian friendship by saying to him that: “You should learn about Syria because the country is a good friend to Russia” (His love for Russia was very well established by then and his Father knew this).

text: He discovered that Damascus is the oldest continuously inhabited city in the world, going back 11,000 years; he learned of the ancient Christian town of Maaloula where the people there speak the language of Jesus Christ, Aramaic; He read about the remarkable Umayyad Mosque in Damascus; he saw photographs of ancient Greek and Roman sites in Syria, such as Apamea and Palmyra; he was spellbound by the beauty of the Syrian coastline; he was enthused by how Syria had one of the lowest crime rates of any country in the world; he was fascinated by the ancient and mysterious ethnic and religious groups in the country, such as the Druze and the Assyrians; he was delighted at the close relationship between Syria and Yugoslavia, under Hafez Al-Assad and Josip Broz Tito, respectively; and he was captivated by how mosques and churches stood side by side in Syria, with imams and priests holding prayers in each other’s temples (Syria is one of the most successful examples of multiculturalism anywhere in the world).
